newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek stocks firm as bank shares strengthen.
newsitem.headline: Greek stocks firm as bank shares strengthen.

text.p: The Athens general share index was trading 1.10 percent higher in early trade after scenarios on the low profitability of certain banks were ruled out, market watchers said.

"On Wednesday, the session will end firmer. There is no more concern about the low profitability of the banking sector, so the index will go up," said John Vezanis, the chairman at Midland Hellenobretanniki Mutual Funds.
Special concern with regard to the share of the National Mortgage Bank NMGr.AT due to its low profits has also subsided, he added.
Vezanis said the 1997 outlook for the Greek bourse was very positive.
Another assistant portfolio manager said the benchmark index would fluctuate plus or minus 0.5 percent on Wednesday.

"I think the market is directionless and I can only predict a 0.5 percent fluctuation for the benchmark index, on a daily basis," said assistant portfolio manager at Allianz Mutual Funds, Yianna Tziovara.
Greece's current account deficit rose 59 percent year-on-year to $4.5 billion in 1996, the widening reflecting a 7.1 percent higher trade deficit of $18.3 billion.
The Athens general share index was trading 1.10 percent or 15.39 points higher at 1,410.28 from Tuesday's 1,394.89 close, after opening at 1,400.87.

The ING Baring Financial Products American style call warrant based on a basket of six bank stocks was quoted higher at $55.90-$57.60. The strike price is set at $99.60 and the warrants expire October 8, 1997.
The ING Baring Financial Products American- style call warrant on a basket of six blue-chips denominated in drachmas was quoted at 1,879-2,069 drachmas.
The strike price is set at 10,000 drachmas and the warrants expire on February 2, 1998.

The recently launched ING Baring American-style second call warrant on a basket of six bank stocks was quoted higher at $11.43-$13.13. The strike price is set at $110.0 and the warrants expire April 9 1998. --Margarita Sotiropoulou, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
